title: Rachel Williams and Lucia Garcia talk through Manchester United Women historic victory over Chelsea - Man United News And Transfer News
body_text:
Manchester United Women reached the final of the FA Cup this weekend to the delight of 6800 fans in Leigh Sports Village. They held on for a 2-1 victory over Chelsea, beating the current Champions for the first time in their 11 meetings.
Unitedâ€™s goal scorers, Lucia Garcia and Rachel Williams were visibly emotional at the final whistle as they spoke to club media, with the sound of their team-matesâ€™ dressing room celebrations audible in the background.
â€œIâ€™m so tired but so happy,â€ Garcia gushed. â€œItâ€™s the first time weâ€™ve beaten Chelsea and the best time to do it because weâ€™re through to the final for the second year in a row.â€
Garcia was surprised to learn that her goal came just 42 seconds into the game after Leah Galton won the ball and charged down the left. She delivered a cross into the box and Garcia headed it past Hannah Hampton.
â€œWow! It was an amazing moment but we have to work hard now to win the final at Wembley,â€ Garcia said.
Williams doubled Unitedâ€™s lead with another header in the 23rd minute. Ella Toone provided the assist.
â€œIt was a rewrite of last yearâ€™s final and thereâ€™s no easy route to the final,â€ Williams said. â€œTo put in the hard work we have, the staff, the players the fans, they were absolutely brilliant.
â€œWeâ€™re going to enjoy today and then look forward to the final and hopefully, fingers crossed, we might just be able to win it.â€
It was a gritty performance from United, who had to defend resolutely for much of the game. Lauren James clawed one back just before half-time but United held on for the win.
It was an intense and physical game which Mary Earps described to the BBC post match as being â€œhorribleâ€ but United found a way to win.
Williams continued: â€œThe manager wanted to change things up. Iâ€™ve been in this league a long time, Iâ€™m not bothered about playing pretty football. If we have to play long ball, pretty football, pattern football, you play whatever you need to win games. We wanted to have players that were not only going to work hard on the ball but off it as well.â€
In the second half, Williams took a ball to the face as she tried to prevent Hampton from hoofing it up the field.
â€œA big part of my game is physicality, a lot of people were saying about how I took the ball in the face off the keeper and you just get on with it. Iâ€™ll do it, because whatâ€™s more important is that we do our jobs out there and we got our rewards today.â€
Williams praised Earps for her â€œbrilliantâ€ performance as she made seven big saves to maintain Unitedâ€™s lead.
â€œThatâ€™s why sheâ€™s had the accolades sheâ€™s had over the last few years because when you need your keeper to step up in big moments sheâ€™s done that.â€
Maya Le Tissier posted on social media following the game that it was 89 minutes of defending for United and again Williams beamed with pride as she spoke of her team-mate.
â€œRight at the end Mayaâ€™s doing diving headers, nearly getting kicked in the face. I think with the ups and downs of this season that weâ€™ve had, when this is what youâ€™ve got left to play for, I ainâ€™t going home tonight sitting on the sofa thinking I wish weâ€™d done this, I wish weâ€™d done that, weâ€™ve given absolutely everything we can and thatâ€™s the reward.â€
After the game, the club posted footage of the players dancing and singing in the dressing room.

Williams joked, â€œZel says drinks on gaffer but I say two days off because after that, my bodyâ€™s going to be battered!â€
United will now switch their focus to the league as they host Tottenham next weekend in what will feel like a practice for the final as Spurs beat Leicester to guarantee their place at Wembley on May 12th.
